results.title: Sweet and lowdown
results.creator_credit: Woody Allen, Jean Doumanian, Sony Pictures Classics and Sweetland Films BV
results.brief_description: Set in the 1930s “Sweet and lowdown” is about a jazz musician who achieves a certain level of fame and respect, with his fingerpicking style. Sean Penn plays Emmet Ray, a talented and vain musician who is socially gauche with a crude personality and amoral ways. When Ray is not playing, he is pimping, thieving or shooting rats at the dump for fun. Ray suffers from an inferiority complex to the famous jazz guitarist Django Reinhardt with whom he constantly compares himself. Despite considering that settling down is detrimental to his artistic drive, Ray forms a deep emotional attachment to a mute girl named Hattie (Samantha Morton) who is enchanted by his music. “Sweet and lowdown” retains a light comical edge throughout and should prove delightful to fans of jazz guitar. As a part of its mockumentary style, several contemporary interviews with jazz experts, including Woody Allen, give insight into Ray’s talent, collectively pondering his mysterious demise. Also stars: Anthony LaPaglia, Uma Thurman and Gretchen Mol.

results.title: The man who played god
results.creator_credit: John G. Adolfi, Darryl F. Zanuck and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Adapted from the play by Jules Eckert Goodman, based on a short story by Gouverneur Morris. Romantic drama starring George Arliss, Violet Heming, Bette Davis.

results.title: Love is a many-splendored thing = Love is a many splendored thing [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Henry King, Buddy Adler and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Adapted from the novel by Han Suyin, “Love is a many splendored-thing” is a film about an inter-racial romance, shot on location in Hong Kong and filmed in Cinemascope. Set in Hong Kong 1949, the film centres on the love affair of Dr Han Suyin (Jennifer Jones) and Mark Elliot (William Holden). She is a dedicated and talented doctor of Eurasian background, working in a local hospital, who longs for her Chinese homeland. He is an American war correspondent covering the Korean War, temporarily based in Hong Kong. When Suyin meets Elliot she is alerted to the fact that he is married and is warned that a cross-cultural relationship is a perilous move. The racism and snobbery of the British social network of Hong Kong is made clear, particularly in the initial stages of the film. The expectations of Suyin’s Chinese family and colleagues are that she will behave in the culturally expectant Chinese way. Suyin is proud of her Eurasian heritage but is also made acutely aware of her cultural difference and status as an outsider, despite being respected professionally. Winner of three Academy Awards, including Best Song.

results.title: Equus
results.creator_credit: Sidney Lumet, Denis Holt, Elliott Kastner, Lester Persky and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Peter Firth plays Alan Strang, a young man working as a stableboy at an upper-class riding school who one night brutally blinds the horses. Richard Burton is psychiatrist Dr. Martin Dysart who is investigating the reasons for the young man’s apparent senseless crime. Based on Peter Shaffer’s acclaimed play, “Equus” is a film that explores and manages to traverse a rich field of themes and concerns: psychoanalysis and mythology; sexuality and repression; class and family; sex and power. The relationship between analyst and patient becomes increasingly complex as the mysteries of the boy’s repressions become unravelled. The men’s exchanges begin to be complicated by the echoes of homoeroticism and the psychological overtones of the Oedipal Complex. Though dominated by the performances of Burton and Firth, “Equus” features an excellent supporting cast including Joan Plowright, Eileen Atkins and Jenny Agutter. Initially dividing critics, “Equus” has become a cult favourite through the years and is acknowledged as one of Lumet’s darker and innovative works.

results.title: 8 1/2 = Eight and a half [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Federico Fellini, Angelo Rizzoli, Cineriz and Francinex
results.brief_description: After the international success of “La Dolce Vita” Fellini found himself in the position of an “overnight sensation”, with critics, audiences and cinema producers expecting his next film to be even more of a success. His predicament caused him to experience a self-doubting of his intellect and creativity, a self-doubt that he managed to commit to screen in this wonderful film. For “8 1/2” is about the struggle to create cinema; about the financial, creative, physical and mental exertions needed to produce a film. Marcello Mastroianni plays a film director, Guido Anselmi, who is beset by adoring fans, angry mistresses, nervous financial backers and hostile critics while in the process of directing his current film. Mixing autobiography, fantastical dream sequences, imaginative sets and starkly photographed childhood memories, “8 1/2” is the most entertaining and stimulating film ever made about film-making. Cast includes Claudia Cardinale, Anouk Aimee and Barbara Steele. Music score by Nino Rota. Voted second best film ever made by a “Sight and Sound” international poll in 1992. The film won the Best Foreign Film Oscar in 1963.

results.title: Bread and tulips = Pane e tulipani
results.creator_credit: Silvio Soldini, Daniele Maggioni and Monogatari
results.brief_description: Bread and tulips is an Italian comedy directed by Silvio Soldini, starring his wife, Licia Maglietta. It is the story of Rosalba, a suburban housewife, living in Pescara, Italy with her two teenage sons and boorish husband. On a tour of Italy with her family Rosalba is accidentally left behind at a depot as the bus departs without her. Dismayed that her family could allow this to happen, Rosalba heads back to Pescara, but on a whim decides to take a side trip to Venice, a city she has always longed to see. Once there, Rosalba begins to question the meaning of her life and the role that she plays in the family unit. Rosalba takes up residency in Vencie, engaging with many colourful characters including, Fernando Girasoli (Bruno Ganz), a depressed Finnish waiter, who offers Rosalba a place to stay and Grazia, (Marina Massironi), his eccentric neighbour, a holistic masseuse. Meanwhile, back in Pescara, Rosalba’s domineering husband, who is not coping domestically in her absence, sends an amateur sleuth (Guiseppe Battiston) to search for her. Shot on location in Venice, “Bread and tulips” explores notions of identity and of discovering the meaning of life. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: The Lady Eve [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Preston Sturges, Paul Jones and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Henry Fonda is a millionaire scientist who is obsessed by snakes. Barbara Stanwyck is the fearless gambler and hustler whose only phobia is reptiles. When they meet on an ocean liner in Latin America, the scene is set for one of Hollywood’s classiest, most electric and funniest of romantic screwball comedies. The dour serious Fonda is a delightful foil to Stanwyck’s vivacious smart-talking Eve. William Demarest plays Fonda’s cynical wary man-servant who does his best to keep Eve away from the innocent Fonda. But Eve has lots of tricks up her sleeve. The effortless charm of this movie is a testament to the wry comic talents of Preston Sturges. Whereas Ernst Lubitsch’s legacy to romantic comedy was a highly stylised European elegance, Sturges took Lubitsch’s blue-print and invested it with American physicality and vigor. The eroticism of the charge between Stanwyck and Fonda is earthy and tangible. The fast script is full of great one-liners, the costumes by Edith Head are delightful, and the supporting cast include some of Hollywood’s finest comic character actors. Watch out for the excellent animated title sequence at the beginning of the movie.

results.title: Extreme prejudice
results.creator_credit: Walter Hill, Buzz Feitshans, Carolco Pictures and Tri-Star Pictures
results.brief_description: Director Walter Hill helms this macho neo-Western with aplomb, providing a plethora of violence and mayhem, in the style of Sam Peckinpah (Hill worked as a screenwriter on several Peckinpah films). Nick Nolte plays Jack Benteen, a Texas Ranger with an incendiary attitude (that apes Dirty Harry), driven by the lawlessness and brutality that has invaded his hometown since the drug trade has escalated there. Heading a key operation is former friend, Cash Bailey; Cash and Benteen are in love with the same sexy Mexican woman, currently Benteen’s girlfriend, which incenses their conflict. Benteen’s success in disarming his former friend is limited and he is countered by a crack team of mercenaries, all ex-army and officially dead or missing, who have been engaged to eliminate Cash and his merciless crew. The bloodshed in this film is quite relentless, lots of bullet-riddled bodies and big guns, interspersed with numerous high tech crimes. Hill tries to keep the central conflict interesting but the variety of sub-plots and the many scenes of testosterone fuelled vicious encounters, muddies the narrative focus.

results.title: How to steal a million
results.creator_credit: William Wyler, Fred Kohlmar and World Wide Productions
results.brief_description: How to steal a million is a romantic comedy caper film that re-teams star Audrey Hepburn and director William Wyler thirteen years after their classic film “Roman holiday” was made. “How to steal a million” is set among the high-end fine art world of museums, collectors, dealers and con-artists. Audrey Hepburn plays Nicole Bonnet, who’s father Charles (Hugh Griffith) specialises in art fraud, in particular ‘lost’ van Gogh masterpieces, which go on to command high prices at auction. Charles’ prized (fake) Cellini sculpture, Venus, is loaned for a public exhibition in Paris. Fearing that her father’s forgery will be discovered Nicole enlists the help of renowned art thief Simon Dermott (Peter O’Toole) to steal the sculpture. O’Toole plays the charming thief and Hepburn’s love interest with aplomb. The Paris setting and couture clothes (by Givenchy) for Hepburn make “How to steal a million” a delight to watch. Also stars Eli Wallach with a guest appearance by Charles Boyer.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Wyler, Fred Kohlmar and World Wide Productions

Fearing that her father’s forgery will be discovered Nicole enlists the help of renowned art thief Simon Dermott (Peter O’Toole) to steal the sculpture. O’Toole plays the charming thief and Hepburn’s love interest with aplomb. The Paris setting and couture clothes (by Givenchy) for Hepburn make “How to steal a million” a delight to watch. Also stars Eli Wallach with a guest appearance by Charles Boyer.
description_for_label: How to steal a million is a romantic comedy caper film that re-teams star Audrey Hepburn and director William Wyler thirteen years after their classic film “Roman holiday” was made. “How to steal a million” is set among the high-end fine art world of museums, collectors, dealers and con-artists. Audrey Hepburn plays Nicole Bonnet, who’s father Charles (Hugh Griffith) specialises in art fraud, in particular ‘lost’ van Gogh masterpieces, which go on to command high prices at auction. Charles’ prized (fake) Cellini sculpture, Venus, is loaned for a public exhibition in Paris. Fearing that her father’s forgery will be discovered Nicole enlists the help of renowned art thief Simon Dermott (Peter O’Toole) to steal the sculpture. O’Toole plays the charming thief and Hepburn’s love interest with aplomb. The Paris setting and couture clothes (by Givenchy) for Hepburn make “How to steal a million” a delight to watch. Also stars Eli Wallach with a guest appearance by Charles Boyer.

results.title: I Love you to death
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Kasdan, Jeffrey Lurie, Ron Moler, Chestnut Hill Productions and Tri-Star Pictures
results.brief_description: Joey Boca is a philandering pizza shop owner whose wife Rosalie turns a blind eye to his indiscretions until she spies him fondling a woman in the library aisles. Her initial reaction is to contemplate suicide, but her mother advises otherwise - eliminate the rat and be done with it. So Rosalie and her mother set about finding a killer, but their inept choices result in failure and a comedy of errors. Despite repeated attempts using a variety of methods, Joey appears to be invincible. Directed with bland efficiency by Lawrence Kasdan (The Big chill, The Accidental tourist, Grand Canyon, French kiss), this is a black comedy that ponders notions of fidelity and loyalty, albeit in a screwball manner. The original script is peppered with agreeable jokes but strains too hard to convince the audience that despite its dark premise, the filmmakers are only joking. The bright spot here is the ensemble cast in a range of unusual guises: William Hurt as a bummed out hippie, River Phoenix as a love sick would be murderer, Kevin Kline as a two-timing Italian. Based on a true story. Cast also includes Keanu Reeves, Tracey Ullman and Heather Graham.
